newsitem.title: INDIA: India alliance to discuss oil subsidies on May 25.
newsitem.headline: India alliance to discuss oil subsidies on May 25.

text.p: The decision-making Steering Committee of India's ruling United Front coalition will meet on May 25 to discuss ways to contain the country's gaping oil pool deficit, the alliance's spokesman said on Saturday.

Spokesman Jaipal Reddy told reporters the panel, which met on Saturday, could not take a decision on plugging the deficit because neither Finance Minister P. Chidambaram nor junior Petroleum Minister T.R. Balu were present.

"No consensus also emerged among members on what steps had to be taken on the issue of the oil pool account," Reddy said. "Therefore we have decided again to meet on 25th of this month to discuss the oil pool account and other issues."

The oil pool deficit is the amount the government pays state-run oil companies in subsidies for selling their products at well below global prices. The deficit was estimated at 155 billion rupees ($4.33 billion) at the beginning of 1997/98.

Balu said on Monday that the government was considering ways to plug the deficit. Last week Prime Minister Inder Kumar Gujral said the government needed to take a bold decision to contain the deficit.

Balu has said that if excise and import duties are reduced by 15 percent for crude oil and petroleum products the oil pool deficit could be wiped out, the Sunday Times of India reported on Sunday. It also said Balu has called for subsidies on kerosene and diesel to be borne by the general exchequer. ($1=35.8 rupees)
